Description: Charles River Laboratories International Inc. agreed to pay the U.S. government $1.8 million to settle claims that it violated the False Claims Act by improperly charging for labor and other associated costs that were not actually provided on certain National Institutes of Health contracts.

Primary Offense: Medicare Parts C and D Enforcement Action

Description: Genesis Healthcare Inc. agreed to pay the federal government $53,639,288.04, including interest, to settle six federal lawsuits and investigations alleging that companies and facilities acquired by Genesis violated the False Claims Act by causing the submission of false claims to government health care programs for medically unnecessary therapy and hospice services, and grossly substandard nursing care.

Hartford Hospital entered into a $2,469,374 settlement agreement to resolve allegations that it submitted claims in which patients who received home health services within three days of the patients' release from Hartford were improperly coded as discharged rather than as a post-acute care transfer.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General

Description: Kaiser Foundation Health System Inc. paid $850,000 to settle allegations that a Kaiser Permanente pharmacy in Modesto violated the Controlled Substances Act by improperly filling defective prescriptions and by failing to maintain accurate records.

Company: christus st. vincent regional medical center
Description: CHRISTUS St. Vincent Regional Medical Center and its partner CHRISTUS Health agreed to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by making illegal donations to county governments, which were used to fund the state share of Medicaid payments to the hospital.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Chemed Corporation and various wholly-owned subsidiaries, including Vitas Hospice Services LLC and Vitas Healthcare Corporation, agreed to pay $75 million to resolve a government lawsuit alleging that defendants submitted false claims for hospice services to Medicare.

Four Houston-area hospitals affiliated with HCA -- Bayshore Medical Center, Clear Lake Regional Medical Center, West Houston Medical Center and East Houston Regional Medical Center -- agreed to pay $8.6 million to settle allegations they received kickbacks from various ambulance companies in exchange for rights to the hospitals' more lucrative Medicare and Medicaid transport referrals.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Western District of North Carolina

Description: CareCore settled allegations that it authorized medical diagnostic procedures paid for with Medicare and Medicaid funds over a period of at least eight years without properly assessing whether the procedures were necessary or reasonable.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: The Justice Department announced settlements with two physician groups for allegedly receiving illegal remuneration in exchange for patient referrals to hospitals owned by the now-defunct Health Management Associates.

DaVita Rx LLC, a nationwide pharmacy that specializes in serving patients with severe kidney disease, agreed to pay a total of $63.7 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations relating to improper billing practices and unlawful financial inducements to federal healthcare program beneficiaries.
